articles.headline: Amazon Abruptly Fires Senior Managers Tied to Unionized Warehouse
articles.snippet: Company officials said the terminations were the result of an internal review, while the fired managers saw it as a response to the recent union victory.
articles.abstract: Company officials said the terminations were the result of an internal review, while the fired managers saw it as a response to the recent union victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Amazon employees at a massive warehouse on Staten Island scored an upset union victory last month, it turned the union’s leaders into celebrities, sent shock waves through the broader labor movement and prompted politicians around the country to rally behind Amazon workers. Now it also appears to have created fallout within Amazon’s management ranks.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: In a seismic election shift in Northern Ireland, the pro-unity Sinn Fein is winning.
articles.snippet: Final results should be available by Saturday. Some fear it could rekindle unrest between Catholics and Protestants.
articles.abstract: Final results should be available by Saturday. Some fear it could rekindle unrest between Catholics and Protestants.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Northern Ireland was created a century ago, in the wake of a nationalist uprising, to protect the rights of its predominantly Protestant, pro-British population. But on Friday, the largest Irish nationalist party, Sinn Fein, was on the cusp of being declared the territory’s largest party, a political watershed in a land long torn by sectarian violence.

articles.headline: Turning Tables on Russia With West’s Arms, Ukraine Goes on Offense
articles.snippet: Ukrainian forces are seeking to drive back Russian invaders from two key cities in northeast Ukraine and achieve a breakthrough in what has become a grinding battle.
articles.abstract: Ukrainian forces are seeking to drive back Russian invaders from two key cities in northeast Ukraine and achieve a breakthrough in what has become a grinding battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: KRAKOW, Poland — Ukrainian troops, emboldened by sophisticated weapons and long-range artillery supplied by the West, went on the offensive Friday against Russian forces in the northeast, seeking to drive them back from two key cities as the war plunged more deeply into a grinding, town-for-town battle.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora, Cora Engelbrecht and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Recast Abortion Stance, Wary of Voter Backlash
articles.snippet: While Democrats decry a draft opinion that would eliminate the constitutional right to an abortion, Republicans who worked decades for this moment have been largely silent.
articles.abstract: While Democrats decry a draft opinion that would eliminate the constitutional right to an abortion, Republicans who worked decades for this moment have been largely silent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates as the Senate votes on abortion rights.

articles.headline: Russia’s Grave Miscalculation: Ukrainians Would Collaborate
articles.snippet: Besides their military failures, the Russians entered the war believing they could persuade Ukrainians in the east to join their side. Those efforts have failed spectacularly.
articles.abstract: Besides their military failures, the Russians entered the war believing they could persuade Ukrainians in the east to join their side. Those efforts have failed spectacularly.
articles.lead_paragraph: KRYVYI RIH, Ukraine — The solicitation to commit treason came to Oleksandr Vilkul on the second day of the war, in a phone call from an old colleague.

articles.headline: Where Does the Anti-Abortion Movement Go After Roe?
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court draft opinion signals a new era for the 50-year effort to end the constitutional right to abortion. Next goals include a national ban and, in some cases, classifying abortion as homicide.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court draft opinion signals a new era for the 50-year effort to end the constitutional right to abortion. Next goals include a national ban and, in some cases, classifying abortion as homicide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates as the Senate votes on abortion rights.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham

articles.headline: Russian Pullback Seen Near Kharkiv, Despite Victory Day Push for Gains
articles.snippet: Advances by Ukrainian forces in the northeast appeared to have forced Russians to move back toward the border, blowing up bridges behind them and contradicting the Kremlin narrative.
articles.abstract: Advances by Ukrainian forces in the northeast appeared to have forced Russians to move back toward the border, blowing up bridges behind them and contradicting the Kremlin narrative.
articles.lead_paragraph: SLOVIANSK, Ukraine — Russia’s push to give its president a showcase victory in Ukraine appeared to face a new setback on Saturday, as Ukrainian defenders pushed the invaders back toward the northeast border and away from the city of Kharkiv, with the Russians blowing up bridges behind them.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz, Cora Engelbrecht and Megan Specia

articles.headline: A Pot of U.N. Money. Risk-Taking Officials. A Sea of Questions.
articles.snippet: A little-known United Nations agency decided to make an impact by doling out loans and grant money — all to a single family. It did not go well.
articles.abstract: A little-known United Nations agency decided to make an impact by doling out loans and grant money — all to a single family. It did not go well.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the United Nations, two officials had a problem. The little-known agency they ran found itself with an extra $61 million, and they didn’t know what to do with it.
articles.byline: By David A. Fahrenthold and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: As Poor Nations Seek Covid Pills, Officials Fear Repeat of AIDS Crisis
articles.snippet: The antiviral pills, plentiful in the United States, are scarce overseas. Health groups and the White House want to expand access but face obstacles that evoke the H.I.V. epidemic.
articles.abstract: The antiviral pills, plentiful in the United States, are scarce overseas. Health groups and the White House want to expand access but face obstacles that evoke the H.I.V. epidemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A devastating virus was laying waste to nations that lacked medicines available to Americans. The pills were patented and pricey. Poor countries lacked refrigeration to store them, the thinking went, and patients would not be able to follow the complex dosing regimen.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Leak Inquiry Exposes Gray Area of Press Protections
articles.snippet: No law or written code of conduct prescribes how an investigation into the leak of a draft opinion should proceed, or whether journalists will be swept into it.
articles.abstract: No law or written code of conduct prescribes how an investigation into the leak of a draft opinion should proceed, or whether journalists will be swept into it.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a well-established but uneven pattern in American law that applies to government secrets and the journalists who uncover them. The First Amendment generally protects the publication of a leak, but not the leaker.

articles.headline: Seizing an Oligarch’s Assets Is One Thing. Giving Them to Ukraine Is Another.
articles.snippet: It could take years for Russian assets seized by the United States to be permanently confiscated and sold to benefit the Ukrainian people. The Biden administration wants to speed up the process.
articles.abstract: It could take years for Russian assets seized by the United States to be permanently confiscated and sold to benefit the Ukrainian people. The Biden administration wants to speed up the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. government was so pleased with its swift seizure of a Russian oligarch’s 255-foot yacht on the Mediterranean island of Majorca last month that it posted a video on YouTube of the moment F.B.I. agents and Spanish authorities clambered up the gangplank. The $90 million yacht owned by Viktor Vekselberg, called the Tango, was the government’s first big prize in a campaign against billionaires with close ties to the Kremlin.

articles.headline: May 9 Is a Revered Day in Russia. For Many, Putin Has Hijacked It.
articles.snippet: Under President Vladimir V. Putin, Victory Day, marking the defeat of Nazi Germany, has come to celebrate modern Russian military might. The war in Ukraine is shifting its meaning further.
articles.abstract: Under President Vladimir V. Putin, Victory Day, marking the defeat of Nazi Germany, has come to celebrate modern Russian military might. The war in Ukraine is shifting its meaning further.
articles.lead_paragraph: Olga Romanova’s grandmother served as a frontline nurse in World War II. She was small and thin, Ms. Romanova said, but somehow carried “big, grown, wounded men” to safety. She met her husband in her four years on the eastern front.

articles.headline: If Roe Falls, Is Same-Sex Marriage Next?
articles.snippet: The leaked draft opinion that would eliminate the constitutional right to abortion sent mixed signals about what other precedents might be at risk.
articles.abstract: The leaked draft opinion that would eliminate the constitutional right to abortion sent mixed signals about what other precedents might be at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Supreme Court heard arguments in December over the fate of the constitutional right to abortion, it was already clear that other rights, notably including same-sex marriage, could be at risk if the court overruled Roe v. Wade.

articles.headline: Both Sides Harden Positions on Anniversary of Nazi Defeat in Europe
articles.snippet: The war in Ukraine was marked by posturing and signaling, with each side ramping up its rhetoric as the battle ground on.
articles.abstract: The war in Ukraine was marked by posturing and signaling, with each side ramping up its rhetoric as the battle ground on.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a day of commemoration of the end of World War II in Europe, the war in Ukraine was marked by posturing and signaling on Sunday, as each side ramped up its rhetoric and resolve.

articles.headline: The Woman Steering Russia’s War Economy
articles.snippet: Elvira Nabiullina got another five-year term as head of Russia’s central bank after quelling the initial market panic over the invasion of Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Elvira Nabiullina got another five-year term as head of Russia’s central bank after quelling the initial market panic over the invasion of Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than a decade, Elvira Nabiullina is steering Russia’s economy through treacherous waters.

articles.headline: Solar Power Offers Puerto Ricans a Lifeline but Remains an Elusive Goal
articles.snippet: The island’s energy grid has struggled to recover after Hurricane María almost wiped it out in 2017. While solar-power systems can fill gaps, they aren’t cheap.
articles.abstract: The island’s energy grid has struggled to recover after Hurricane María almost wiped it out in 2017. While solar-power systems can fill gaps, they aren’t cheap.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Puerto Rico reeled from its worst power outage in months, one that left virtually all of the island’s 1.5 million customers without electricity for days, the town of Adjuntas was an oasis.
articles.byline: By Coral Murphy Marcos and Erika P. Rodriguez

articles.headline: Stock market’s plunge continues on new concerns about global economy.
articles.snippet: New data from China is adding to worries over high inflation, rising interest rates and supply chain disruptions.
articles.abstract: New data from China is adding to worries over high inflation, rising interest rates and supply chain disruptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s relentless decline stretched into a sixth week on Monday, fueled by new data from China that added to concerns about a global economy that’s being battered by high inflation, rising interest rates and a malfunctioning supply chain.

articles.headline: Russia’s invasion upends a shared World War II history with Ukraine.
articles.snippet: The war has complicated relationships between Russians and Ukrainians.
articles.abstract: The war has complicated relationships between Russians and Ukrainians.
articles.lead_paragraph: She carried a simple bouquet of white lilacs as explosions reverberated through the bright spring air. Tears streaked her weathered face, which was framed by a blue head scarf.

articles.headline: In Speech, Putin Shows Reluctance in Demanding Too Much of Russians
articles.snippet: The Russian president, in a much-anticipated speech on his country’s most important holiday, did not proclaim an escalation of the fight in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: The Russian president, in a much-anticipated speech on his country’s most important holiday, did not proclaim an escalation of the fight in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: He made no claim of victory or “mission accomplished” and no promise that the fight in Ukraine could end soon. But as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke in Moscow’s Red Square on Monday, he also made no call for new sacrifice or mobilization, no threat of a nuclear strike, no stark pronouncement about an existential war with the West.
